result.execSummary:
The defendant Sarah L. TEGELMAN was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Deliver Cocaine (<=1g), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(cm)1g.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with the sentence presently being served on 11 CF 352.

superMiscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Pay supervision fees in an amount to be determined by the Department of Corrections.

Maintain absolute sobriety and no contact with any bars or liquor stores.

Assessment, treatment, counseling as deemed appropriate by the Department's assessment process.

No contact with any known drug dealers or users.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Sarah L. TEGELMAN

Letter from DA LaBre to Court.

Letter from Defendant to Judge J. Fox, dated 10-28-2014
RE: Return of money from Metro Drug

Letter from Judge J. Fox to DA Atty. J. LaBre, dated 11-07-2014
Re: Return of money from Metro Drug.

Transcript of plea and sentencing hearing held on 07-31-14.
Copy of transcript mailed to Registrar at Taycheedah Correctional Institution.

Defendant in custody on WRIT.
The State moves to dismiss the repeater enhancer.  Court grants motion.
GUILTY plea entered to the amended charge of deliver cocaine. Convicted.
The defendant is sentenced to the Wisconsin State Prison System for a total of three (3) years.  That is one (1) year initial confinement followed by two (2) years extended supervision, concurrent with the sentence presently being served in 11 CF 352.
The Court finds the defendant eligible for both the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program.
Conditions of extended supervision:
1) Pay court costs;
2) pay supervision fees in an amount to be determined by DOC;
3) maintain absolute sobriety and have no contact with any bars or liquor stores;
4) assessment, treatment, counseling as deemed appropriate by the Departments assessment process;
5) no contact with any known drug dealers or users.
